awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Weighted Estimates with Matrix Weights and Non-Homogeneous Harmonic Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Calderon-Zygmund operators are objects that are largely responsible for our understanding of a number of physical phenomena, from heat transfer to turbulence. Recently, these operators have found application in big data analysis. The classical theory was built by Alberto Calderon and Antoni Zygmund in the early 1950s, and was intrinsically designed to work on smooth objects. However, nature often puzzles us with very irregular medium. Thus, the need arose for a very low regularity Calderon-Zygmund theory, which the three PIs have, in fact, constructed. One possible application of such low regularity theory is that by the action of Calderon-Zygmund operators on a set in a space of a very high dimension, we can conclude that the set itself is nicely structured and can be analyzed. This is a typical big data problem. Our other recent observation is that well-studied problems for such an operator can be dualized to provide new information for analysis on the hypercube - another widely used model of big data.

This project will consider the following problems, presented here in their simplest by formulation: 1) Sharp end-point weak weighted estimates for the square function operator in the homogeneous setting; 2) What goes wrong in the non-homogeneous case; 3) Matrix A_2 problems for Calderon--Zygmund operators, the square function operator, their sparse operators analogies and their sharp estimates; 4) How to get from end-point estimates of the square function to geometric inequalities on the hypercube and in Gaussian space; 5) The David-Semmes problem for co-dimension higher than one; 6) Harmonic measure estimates on sets of co-dimension bigger than one; and 7) Estimates from below of singular Riesz transforms by positive geometric quantities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research was of purely theoretical nature, and the main outcomes were theorems obtained in the process as well as connections with other areas of mathematics. It also served as a training ground for graduate students and young mathematicians working under supervision of PI.

Among the outcomes of the research are: 

A series of new result about matrix-valued Clark measures and their connections with perturbation theory were obtained in collaboration with C. Liaw. In particular, the generalization of the Aronszajn-Donoghue theorem about singular spectrum was generalized to the case of matrix-valued measures; new phenomenon of "directionality" of matrix valued measures was discovered and played an important role there. 

In collaboration with F. Nazarov, S. Petermichl, and K. Skreb we proved that, unlike the scalar case, the weighted maximal function with matrix weight is not bounded. This result was quite unexpected (one can even say shocking) and should be useful in the non-commutative harmonic analysis. 

New and unexpected results about the inverse spectral problem for Hankel operators, were obtained in a joint work with P. Gerard and A. Pushnitskii. While initial motivation for studying inverse problems for Hankel operators comes from probability, the interest in the problem was renewed after P. Gerard and S. Grellier discovered connections with the so-called cubic Szego equation, which is a model completely integrable Hamiltonian system. For the case of simple spectrum we completely described the spectral data (the spectral information needed to describe the operator). We also proved that not all spectral data correspond to some Hankel operator, i.e. disproved the so called "surjectivity conjecture", that for some time considered undisputable.
